meanings.def: to say numbers in the correct order
examples: Billy can't count yet.
count (up) to something She can count up to 10 in Italian.
count from something (to/up to something) to count from 1 to 10
He can now count from one to twenty.
We counted up to fifty, then set off to look for our friends.

meanings.def: to calculate the total number of people, things, etc. in a particular group
examples: count something (up) They're still counting votes in Texas.
I can't count the number of times I've eaten there (= I've eaten there very many times).
The diet is based on counting calories.
count (up) how many… She began to count up how many guests they had to invite.
count from… There are twelve weeks to go, counting from today.
She carefully counted the remaining coins and put them to one side.
We counted up our money.

meanings.def: to include somebody/something when you calculate a total
examples: We have invited 50 people, not counting the children.
The tour guide was sure one person was missing from the group until she realized she had forgotten to count herself.

meanings.def: to be important
examples: It is going to be a close election, so every vote counts.
Every point in this game counts.
With our busy lives today we have less and less time for what really counts.
It's the thought that counts (= used about a small but kind action or gift).
count for something The fact that she had apologized counted for nothing with him.

meanings.def: to be officially accepted; to accept something officially
examples: Don't go over that line or your throw won't count.
The goal wouldn't have counted anyway, because the linesman's flag was up for offside.
The home team's manager protested that the run should count.
count something Applications received after 1 July will not be counted.

meanings.def: to consider somebody/something in a particular way; to be considered in a particular way
examples: count (somebody/something) as somebody/something For tax purposes that money counts/is counted as income.
count somebody/something/yourself among somebody/something I count him among my closest friends.
count somebody/something/yourself + adj. I count myself lucky to have known him.
count somebody/something/yourself + noun She counts herself one of the lucky ones.
I count it a privilege to have served alongside him.

meanings.def: used to say that a total is continuing to increase
examples: The movie's ticket sales add up to $39 million, and counting.

meanings.def: used to say that the total number of somebody/something is very small
examples: She could count on the fingers of one hand the people she actually enjoyed being with.
Although she knew lots of people, she could count her friends on the fingers of one hand.

meanings.def: to be grateful for the good things in your life
to feel the bad effects of a mistake, an accident, etc.
examples: The town is now counting the cost of its failure to provide adequate flood protection.

meanings.def: to imagine that sheep are jumping over a fence and to count them, as a way of getting to sleep
you should not be too confident that something will be successful, because something may still go wrong
to say publicly that you support somebody or you agree with something
examples: Everyone needs to stand up and be counted in order to make them see the strength of our conviction.

meanings.def: used to say that you do not care how many times something happens
examples: I've seen the film five times, but who's counting?

idioms.def: used to say that a total is continuing to increase
examples: The movie's ticket sales add up to $39 million, and counting.

idioms.idiom: be able to count somebody/something on (the fingers of) one hand
idioms.def: used to say that the total number of somebody/something is very small
examples: She could count on the fingers of one hand the people she actually enjoyed being with.
Although she knew lots of people, she could count her friends on the fingers of one hand.

idioms.def: used to say that you do not care how many times something happens
examples: I've seen the film five times, but who's counting?

meanings.def: an act of counting to find the total number of somebody/something
examples: If the election result is close, there will be a second count.
The bus driver did a quick count of the empty seats.
by somebody's count By my count there are eight tracks here that aren't on the band's three albums.
Our daily count of Web traffic tells us many people are visiting our site.
The vote count should be repeated.
We did a quick count of the children and there were none missing.

meanings.def: an act of saying numbers in order beginning with 1
examples: count of… Raise your leg and hold for a count of ten.
He was knocked to the ground and stayed down for a count of eight (= in boxing).
The referee didn't even finish the count when he saw that Juarez was unable to continue.
on a/the count of… On the count of three, take one step forward.

meanings.def: a measurement of the amount of something contained in a particular substance or area
examples: a raised white blood cell count
Her white cell count has gone down again.
an abnormally high white blood cell count

meanings.def: a crime that somebody is accused of committing
examples: They were found guilty on all counts.
to be charged with two counts of murder
She appeared in court on three counts of fraud.

meanings.def: a point made during a discussion or an argument
examples: I disagree with you on both counts.

meanings.def: a nobleman of high rank, similar to an earl in the UK
examples: Count Tolstoy

meanings.def: according to the latest information about the numbers of something
examples: She'd applied for 30 jobs at the last count.
At the last count she had 43 cats!

meanings.def: to remember or keep a record of numbers or amounts of something over a period of time
examples: Keep a count of your calorie intake for one week.

meanings.def: to forget the total of something before you have finished counting it
examples: I lost count and had to start again.
She had lost count of the number of times she'd told him to be careful (= she could not remember because there were so many).
I've lost count of the times I've heard that joke.

meanings.def: unable to get up again within ten seconds after being knocked down
in a deep sleep
